utterance_text: Hi, Sal. Thanks for coming in today to talk about what's been going on and how you're feeling.
No problem.
I appreciate your doctor referring you here, and I'm glad you took the time to make an appointment.
Yeah, it's a bit of an inconvenience, but I'm here now.
So, you made it in here today, and can you tell me what some of the concerns your doctor had that led her to refer you?
Honestly, I don't know - something about changing my life even more. The smoking's been changed, and now it's cut down on drinking, getting rid of those extra smokes, and getting rid of my dog.
It sounds like there are a lot of changes being suggested to you right now.
Yeah, there's a lot of stress too. My wife is still on maternity leave, not getting paid, and she's with the baby most of the time. And I'm the only one working, so it's a big responsibility.
That must be really overwhelming for you.
Yeah, it feels like everything is all over the place right now.
Almost to the point where it's almost too much to handle.
Yeah, that's exactly how I feel.
Well, we have about 15 or 20 minutes together, and I was wondering if you'd be okay with taking a few minutes to look at all of these changes and see what would be the most helpful to focus on?
Yeah, it just feels like everything is all over the place, but I guess we can start somewhere.
Okay. One tool we use is an agenda-setting worksheet that helps us prioritize things.
Mm-hmm.
So, if you were to list all of the different things people around you are saying you need to work on or change, what would some of those things be?
Okay.
Remember, this is just a way to put everything out there - it doesn't mean you have to make any changes right now.
Okay. Um, okay, that sounds good.
You're in the driver's seat here, so we're just going to put all the cards on the table.
Okay. As long as I'm not changing anything and we're just kind of putting pen to paper or something.
Yep.
Um, okay, so my asthma is one thing that's been bothering me.
Okay, so asthma is one area you'd like to address.
Yeah.
What else would you like to talk about?
Um, the fact that they want me to get rid of Oscar, that's my dog.
So your dog is a big concern for you right now.
Which I don't buy - it's a main contributor to my asthma problems, but I know I can't just get rid of him like that.
That must be really hard for you to hear.
Yeah. The dog has been there before my wife, and I know I've had him longer.
So the loss of your dog is a huge stress right now.
Yeah. It's like my best friend, so that's one of the important things.
And you're also working on quitting smoking completely?
Um, finances is a problem right now too.
Okay, so money is another area you'd like to address.
Time - I've got to come to all these appointments and I'm taking time off work, which obviously affects my income.
Right. So the appointments and time away from work are impacting your finances.
Mm-hmm.
And some of these things seem related to each other, right?
Yeah, yeah. Yeah, there's something going on.
And you're also concerned about cutting down on drinking?
Yeah, my drinking is another thing I need to work on too.
Okay, wow. So there's a lot happening right now, Sal.
No. It just feels overwhelming when you see everything they're saying.
Right. Well, if you had to pick one or two things to focus on in our time together today, where would you like to start?
I think the thoughts about the dog have been definitely bothering me, that's been one.
Okay.
And my asthma is out of control too. So maybe those two.
Those are both related areas - sounds like we're on the right track.
Mm-hmm.
Can you help me understand what's behind your wife's concerns about your health habits?
I don't know, she just seems to be on my case a lot lately.
It sounds like you feel like you're not seeing the issue from her perspective.
Yeah, I mean, I've been working hard and I feel fine.
You mentioned that your job is physically demanding and you often work outdoors. Have you noticed any changes in your body as a result?
Well, I have gained a little weight, but nothing too noticeable.
And when was the last time you visited the doctor for a check-up?
About a year ago, everything seemed fine.
But despite feeling good physically, you're still concerned about your wife's concerns.
Yeah, I guess so.
It seems like you feel like your wife might be overreacting to this situation.
Not really, she just wants me to live a long time and be healthy.
I understand that. Sometimes, taking care of ourselves can make us feel better about our circumstances.
Yeah, going out to eat sometimes makes me feel a little better about my job.
Okay, well let's explore this further. Is there anything you'd like to know about obesity or diabetes?
Sure.
Hello, Barbara. How are you today?
Yes, morning.
Good morning. My name is Dr. Betty, and I'm one of the new GPs in this practice. Can you tell me a little bit about what brings you here today?
Well, I've come about my tummy problem. I've got terrible trouble with my stomach and, uh, Dr. Brown just doesn't seem to be able to get to the bottom of it.
I'm so sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? What's been going on with your stomach?
Um, well, I-I have this terrible discomfort nearly all the time. Um, it very often feels bloated. I, um, uh, I swing between being constipated and having diarrhea.
That sounds really challenging for you. Can you describe what that feeling is like? Is there anything specific that's causing you distress?
Mm.
-and some of them sound quite troublesome to you.
Yes.
Okay, let's explore this further. When did you first start noticing these symptoms, and have they changed over time?

Well, I, uh, I've traced it back to a holiday I had in Egypt about four years ago. I had, um, a horrible bout of sickness and diarrhea, and, uh, and I don't think my stomach's ever been really right since then.
Mm-hmm. Okay. So you think this might be related to that trip?
Yes. Yes.
Okay. Have you tried any treatments or medications for your symptoms so far?
Well, uh, Dr. Brown gave me some muscle relaxants at the beginning.
Mm-hmm.
-and Immodium in my handbag all the time, just in case. Yeah.
I have Immodium in my handbag all the time, just in case. Yeah.
Right. So, you're using these medications to manage your symptoms, but they haven't seemed to make a significant difference?
Mm.

-and maybe trying to bring back some of those pleasurable things, you know, even if it's just meeting up with your female friends once a week, and whether actually doing those sorts of things might generally improve your quality of life.
Mm.
What would you think about trying that slightly different approach for say-say two or three months, just to see whether or not it makes any difference?
Well, two or three months is a long time if there is something going on. I mean, that's what happened to my mother-in-law, you know.
Right. How would that sound? Would you be willing to try this new approach and see how it goes?
Okay. Well, uh, to make an appointment for next week.
Yeah. And perhaps if you could also bring your tablets in or-or make a list of them, we can look at what you're taking and perhaps go from there.
Okay. Well, uh, to make an appointment for next week.
Yes. I think so.
All right. And I'll make a list of the tablets that I'm taking.
Yeah.
I won't bring all the bottles down.
Okay. All right.
Okay. All right. I'll do that.
So, shall I see you again next week?
I'll make an appointment for next week. Yes.
Okay. All right. Thank you, Barbara.
Okay. Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Okay, David. So, why don't you take a rinse, and how are you feeling right now?
Hmm, I'm pretty good, thanks.
Would you like to explore what's making you feel that way about rinsing the sink?
Check it out? Yeah, I'd like to see if it's fixed.
What do you think is going on with this sink, and how does it relate to your feelings?
Oh, that was fixed really nice. It looks great now.
I'm glad to hear that the sink is looking good. Can we talk about what might have caused some discoloration in the first place?
Yeah, I think it's probably related to smoking, wine, and coffee – all of the above.
That makes sense. Have you ever considered quitting smoking as a way to address this issue?
Yeah, I've thought about it. To be honest, I'm just not sure if it would work for me. I've tried before, but it didn't stick.
It can be tough when we're faced with advice from multiple sources, including doctors and loved ones. Can you tell me more about what's holding you back from quitting?
Yeah, yeah, yeah... it's just hard to quit when everyone keeps telling me I need to do it.
I apologize if my words came across as judgmental or lecturing. That wasn't my intention.
Yeah, I know I'm not an idiot, and people know that smokers are a tough crowd – "How can you smoke today?" It's just hard to quit.
I understand that it's not easy when we're faced with advice from multiple sources. Can you tell me more about your past experience with smoking?
I've smoked for 40 years, since I was 14, and I've tried quitting a couple of times in my 20s, but it's been consistent.
That's a long time to be struggling with this habit. Can you tell me more about how smoking fits into your life right now?
No matter what kind of talk I get or what they come up with, I just can't see myself changing now.
It sounds like you've tried many approaches in the past and haven't seen success. What do you think is holding you back from quitting for good this time around?
Not gonna work for me.
Have you considered trying a different approach, such as cold turkey? Many people have found it to be effective.
Yeah, I've heard that before – and then they fight it. But it's my choice, and I don't like lectures about it.
You're absolutely right; nobody has the right to tell you what to do. Can we explore a scenario where you decide to quit smoking? What would be the trigger for that decision?
Hard to tell – I already had open-heart surgery, and that didn't work. Prostate cancer didn't work either.
I'm so sorry to hear that you've faced those challenges. Can we talk more about what's holding you back from quitting now?
I just don't really want it.
So, this is something that you pretty much see yourself doing for a while – quite a while.
Yeah, a while... yeah.

Okay, well, I appreciate your willingness to talk about this. And I get that right now, this isn't something you want to pursue. Would it be okay if we brought it up in our next visit? I'm concerned about your health.
Okay, yeah – I could go for some listening. Yeah.
As long as I don't talk too much?
Yeah... [laughs]
You're glad to keep your surgeon as a doctor, right?
Yeah.
Well, David, wherever you're at, we'll work with it.
Okay.
Thanks for taking a couple of minutes and talking about smoking.
Thanks, doc.
Hi, Mary, how was your day?
It's been fine, I guess.
You seem a bit preoccupied. Is there something on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
No, not really.
Okay, well, it seems like you had a busy morning at school. You missed your first hour of class today.
Yeah, I just didn't feel like going.
It sounds like this isn't a big concern for you right now.
No, it's not.
So, what do you think is the point of our visits together?
I don't know. Why are you asking me all these questions?
I'm trying to understand your perspective and see if there's anything that might be helpful for you.
Yeah, I guess.
Would it be okay with you if I explained again what this program is about?
Okay, I suppose.
I want to make sure you know that my role as your caseworker is to support you and help you succeed.
So you just want to know my business?
I can see how it might seem that way. But I assure you, my goal is to care about you and help you achieve your goals.
Mm-hmm.
Some clients have struggled with understanding that I'm here to support them, not just monitor their behavior.
Yeah.
It's possible that you're feeling a bit overwhelmed by all the rules and expectations.
Yeah. It's like there are too many rules.
I can imagine how frustrating that must be for you.
Mm-hmm.
Some clients have found that having their freedom is more valuable than they realized when it was taken away.
Right, that's what I wish I had now.
What would help you regain your freedom?
Just not doing this again so I don't have to be stuck here.
That makes sense. If you can avoid committing another crime, you'll be able to move forward with your life.
Yup.
I appreciate it when you still sign the paperwork even though it's annoying at times.
Mm-hmm.
Before I leave, is there anything else you'd like to share or discuss?
No, really.
Just a reminder that I'll be back later today to check in with you again.
All right.
Okay, well, take care of yourself for now.
Bye.
Right, so you've hit a plateau in your weight loss and despite all the efforts to increase physical activity, it's not showing up on the scale?
No, I'm just feeling stuck and I don't know what I'm doing wrong because I keep trying different exercises.
So you feel like you're getting nowhere, no matter how hard you try to exercise or make changes.
Yes, it's frustrating.
And when you come home from the gym, do you find that your family members aren't offering the support you need?
No, they don't seem to care about my weight loss efforts at all.
It sounds like you feel like you're doing this alone, without anyone's encouragement or understanding.
Yes, I feel like I'm on my own with this.
Specifically, how does your father's perspective on your weight loss affect you?
He thinks that if I lose weight, I'll be disconnecting from our family and he wants me to focus on gaining weight back.
That must be really tough for you. It sounds like he sees your weight loss as a threat to your relationship with him.
Exactly, it's like he doesn't understand that my goal is just to have a healthy body, not to fit into some idealized image.
Hello, Scott.
Hi.
We were discussing exercising earlier. Can you tell me more about that?
I want to get back into working out, but I've lost my motivation over the past couple of years.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit stuck. What's holding you back from getting started again?
I just got busy and now I'm out of the habit. I feel like I need to get back in shape, especially since I've been gaining weight around my middle.
That makes sense. Let's make a list of reasons why you want to start working out again, and then we can brainstorm some ideas for how to help you get started.
Okay...I guess that sounds like a good idea.
Which gym do you belong to?
It's the Sport Fitness Center, just a couple of miles from my house.
So it's relatively close. That might make it easier for you to find time to go.
If I walked that far, I probably wouldn't need to go to the gym at all.
But regular exercise can have many benefits beyond just physical appearance. It can also improve your cardiovascular health and overall well-being.
Yeah, I know. I want to feel better and be healthier.
That's a great goal. What do you hope to achieve by getting back into working out?
I'd like to lose weight and feel more comfortable in my clothes again.
It sounds like you're looking for a sense of confidence and self-improvement. Let's focus on finding ways to make exercise a sustainable part of your routine.
Yeah, that would be great.
I want to emphasize the importance of taking care of your health over any aesthetic goals. Exercise can have a significant impact on both physical and mental well-being.
I know what you mean. I feel like I'm getting older, and it's time for me to make some changes.
It's never too late to start making positive changes in your life. You've shown that you can do it before, and with a bit of effort, you can get back into the habit.
Yeah, I know what to do.
That's right. It might mean waking up an hour earlier each day or finding other ways to fit exercise into your schedule.
I need to make time for it.
Exactly. And when we meet again next week, I'd like you to try experimenting with getting up a bit earlier and see how that works out for you.
Okay.
Great. Just remember to bring the list of reasons why you want to start working out again, and we can work on finding ways to make it a sustainable part of your routine.
Okay.
I'll see you next week.
Okay, thanks.
Bye for now.
Bye.
Mr. Johnson, can I start by confirming that you're here to discuss your cholesterol and the medication prescribed by your doctor?
Yeah?
As my role is also to support you in understanding how to use your medication effectively and provide information on maximizing its benefits.
Well, I talked with my doctor about my medicine. That's his job.
While your doctor has provided guidance, my goal is to help you make informed decisions about your treatment plan.

Well, to be honest with you, I'm not even certain I'm going to take the medicine. Now, I know I got high cholesterol, I've got to get that down, but on the other hand, this medicine can cause some severe muscle weakness and I just can't afford that. I'm a truck driver and I haul those heavy boxes in on the dollies and I just can't afford that, so you know.
You're concerned about the potential side effects of the medication, particularly the muscle weakness, which is affecting your ability to do your job as a truck driver.
Yeah, down the line, but-
If left untreated, high cholesterol increases the risk of stroke or heart attack; would you like me to elaborate on that?
Well, right now it's the muscle weakness that-that I'm concerned about, and that's, uh, you know, that's the present, uh, I've got to do my job.
I understand your focus is on managing your current situation; however, it's essential to consider the long-term risks associated with high cholesterol.
Well, why don't you just give me the medicine, I'll take it home and I'll think about it? But you know, I'm worried about my job.
You need to take the medication regularly; if you experience muscle weakness, please inform your doctor, who can adjust your treatment plan as needed.
Sure. Fine. Just—
The muscle weakness is a rare side effect, and there are measures in place to minimize its impact on your daily life.
Whatever.
Let's focus on the benefits of taking the medication; it will help you manage your cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of stroke or heart attack.
Okay, sure. Fine.
I want to emphasize that your health is a priority, and I'm here to support you in making informed decisions about your treatment plan.
Okay.

Alright, Chris, I want to discuss this with you because our school has a zero-tolerance policy for drugs and alcohol. As athletic director, it's my responsibility to ensure all student-athletes follow that rule. I've heard rumors about a party this weekend, and although I don't have confirmation, I'm concerned.

Yes, actually, I want to talk to you about something that happened over the past weekend. Normally, as an honor student, I study on weekends and my parents won't let me attend parties, but I used that as leverage to convince them to go with friends who were pressuring me.
I understand.
When I arrived at the party, I felt overwhelmed by the environment and the pressure to drink. I didn't want to be ostracized by my peers.
I get it. We've all been in similar situations. As a school, we have rules in place for a reason, and as a team member, you need to adhere to them.
I know that drinking is bad for me, both physically and mentally. It affects my performance on the field and puts me at risk of being ostracized by my friends.
You're feeling pressure from your peers, which can be challenging as a team leader.
Yes, it's hard to resist when everyone around me is doing it. I feel like I need to fit in with the group.
But you have a responsibility to set an example and lead by example, even in social situations.
That's true. If I don't drink, my teammates might see me as different or judgmental.
Maybe you can find ways to lead without drinking, like being the first one to leave parties or finding alternative activities with your friends.
But what if they ridicule me for it? I'm just one person against a group of peers.
As your coach, my job is to support you in making good choices. We need to find a way to balance having fun with being responsible and adhering to the rules.
Okay, I'll make sure to limit my drinking and be more mindful of what I post online.
That's a great start. Let's work together to find a solution that works for you and the team.
I promise to be more responsible.
Alright, let's shake on it and move forward.
Shake.
Alright, we'll catch up later.
See you later.
So Tom, this infection has been quite painful for you, but we have antibiotics. If you take them faithfully for 10 days, I'm confident that your infection will be resolved. Can you commit to that?
Definitely.
And may I review the screening form you completed earlier today regarding drug use?
Okay.

I occasionally use meth.
Do you typically snort or smoke it?
Snort it; always snort it.
Have you ever injected it?
No.

Just some alcohol.
How often do you use meth?
Meth about two to three times a month.
So, you'd say you're an occasional meth user. You don't use it frequently?
Right.
Is snorting the only way you consume methamphetamine?
Yes.

Given your situation, I want to discuss some health risks associated with Methamphetamine use. Your usage puts you in a category we consider risky. There are several consequences, including sexually transmitted diseases. Do you think your current STD might be related to your Methamphetamine use?
Yeah, it could be because I was high when I had unprotected sex and wouldn't do that if I weren't high.
You normally practice safe sex, correct?
Definitely, yeah.
It seems like methamphetamine may have impaired your judgment during those instances.
Yeah.
Are there any other ways Methamphetamine is affecting you in your life?

No, I mean, no. I only do it in clubs with my friends, usually two or three times a month at most. I don't think it's really impacting me much. But I'm concerned about this one. I never expected to get gonorrhea.
I share your concern, and I'd recommend you stop using Methamphetamine altogether. There are several reasons for this, but that's my recommendation.
I understand, but it would be hard for me to do that. You know, meth is just a part of my social life and sex life.
You recognize the problems associated with Methamphetamine and also see how much of your social life and sex life involves it. Quitting might be challenging.
Yeah, I don't think it would be easy but I'm not saying that I'm not willing to try.
If you were to consider quitting using Methamphetamine completely, with zero being not ready at all and 10 being fully committed, where would you place yourself?
Uh, three.
Why not a one or two? What's holding you back from being more committed?

I mean, this has been really uncomfortable; gonorrhea is a bad experience. And when I'm on meth, I don't think the same way. And what I have now is bad enough; I could easily get AIDS or HIV. That scares me a lot.
Are there any other concerns you have about Methamphetamine?
Well, I do just snort it but you don't know what it's cut with; there could be something really bad if it's mixed with something dangerous.

So, when we first discussed this, I thought you'd have little interest in quitting using Methamphetamine. However, it seems like you have several reasons why you want to stop. That's because of the risks associated with it, including getting a different STD.
Yeah.
What do you think would make it easier for you to reduce or quit using Methamphetamine?
Something else to do on weekends; I need a different social life.
How could you get that different social life?
It's hard because almost everybody I know uses meth.
Is there anyone in your life who doesn't use methamphetamine?
My sister.
Have you talked to her about your Methamphetamine use?
I haven't really talked to her about it. I think she knows; we're pretty close. I could talk to her, and I think she'd help.

On one hand, there are many positives from using meth, but on the other, there are reasons why you want to quit. There might be ways to make it easier, such as talking to your sister and getting support.
Yes.
Well, great. I recommend not using Methamphetamine at all, but what you do is up to you.
Okay.
Would seeing me again in a month work for you?
Yeah, sure.
Hi, I'm Bruce Berger, and I work with patients who have asthma. Can you confirm your name is Julie Thompson?
Yes.
Hi, I'm Bruce Berger. I noticed you're here to pick up a prescription for Sarah's rescue inhaler. Have you experienced any difficulties with her asthma in the last year?
It's been really difficult. Seeing her gasping for breath and worrying about her trips to the emergency room is overwhelming.
I can see that it's causing you significant distress. You'd do anything to prevent those situations, right?
Yes.
I also noticed it's been a few months since you picked up Sarah's chronic inhaler prescription.
Yes.
Are you having trouble with the medication or any concerns about its use?

I researched the chronic inhaler and found out it contains steroids, which I'm not comfortable with. I looked into potential side effects and health problems associated with them and don't want Sarah to take those risks.
You care deeply about Sarah's well-being and want to protect her from harm.
Yes.
Would you be open to discussing the chronic inhaler and its benefits in more detail?
Yes.

The medication is not an anabolic steroid, but rather a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation in Sarah's lungs. It's designed to prevent her asthma symptoms without causing the same side effects as those steroids.
I didn't realize they weren't the same thing.
You're concerned about the potential risks of steroids, which is understandable. However, this medication is specifically designed for people with asthma and has a much lower risk profile.
That's reassuring to know.

When Sarah has an asthma attack, her lungs become extremely sensitive, like skin that's been burned off. This makes her react to even small particles in the air. The chronic inhaler can help reduce this sensitivity and prevent future attacks.
Oh, I see what you mean now.
Using the chronic inhaler regularly can make a significant difference in Sarah's symptoms and reduce her need for rescue medication.
That sounds great.

Additionally, even though you're smoking outside, the smoke on your clothes can still affect Sarah's lungs. If you use the chronic inhaler as directed, she may not be as sensitive to smoke on your clothes.
Even when it's just on my clothes?
Yes, her sensitivity is quite high. However, if she's using the chronic inhaler, the risk of a reaction from smoke on your clothes should decrease significantly.
I'll keep that in mind.
Quitting smoking would be beneficial for both you and Sarah. It would greatly reduce her asthma symptoms and improve her overall health.
Yeah, it is difficult to quit.
If you're willing to try quitting, we can work together to support you. In the meantime, using the chronic inhaler as directed will help manage Sarah's asthma.
Okay.
Let's focus on getting both prescriptions ready and using the chronic inhaler every day. We'll also keep an eye on how it affects Sarah's symptoms and adjust as needed.
That sounds good.
I'm glad we can work together to help Sarah manage her asthma. Thank you for your cooperation.
Thank you.

As we explore different directions for our session, I'd like to clarify that you've mentioned wanting to make changes in your physical activity, eating habits, and body confidence. Can you help me understand what's driving your desire to focus on physical activity as a potential starting point?
I feel like it's the most accessible area for me to begin with, and if I can establish an activity routine, that might create opportunities for other changes in my nutrition and overall well-being.
That makes sense. Physical activity is feeling like the easiest place to start.
Yes, I think so.
What motivates you to get started with physical activity? You've mentioned energy levels, improved mood, and reducing stress – are there any other benefits that resonate with you?
For me, it's about feeling stronger and more capable. Last night, struggling with opening a jar of salsa was a big deal for me, so I think being more active would help with everyday tasks like that.
So, physical strength is an important aspect of your motivation. You also hope to improve your body image and confidence.
Exactly. If I'm more active, I believe my body image will improve too.
On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means you're not ready to make a change in physical activity and 10 means you're fully committed, where do you fall?
I'd say an 8 – I'm feeling fairly motivated.
You're close to being fully on board. What's holding you back from choosing a higher number?
I've identified many benefits of being more active, including improved mood, energy, and self-confidence. That's what's driving my motivation.
It sounds like the potential benefits are overwhelming you – there's too much to gain from physical activity.
Yes, that's true.
Am I missing any other aspects of your motivation?
I don't think so.
Okay, those seem to be the main drivers for you. Now we can start exploring how physical activity might look in your life and what activities you might enjoy.
That sounds great.
Let's dive into that.

I wanted to talk to you about some concerns I saw on Facebook that made me think of you, Tommy. You're a good kid, and I'm worried that drinking might be affecting your life in ways you're not seeing right now.
I was just at a social gathering with friends, and we were all having fun together. It wasn't like I was looking for trouble; the drinks were there, and everyone was doing it.

I understand that, but there are so many consequences to drinking, especially when you're underage. You could get arrested, have a drunk driving accident, or mess up your schoolwork. Your future is bright, and I'm concerned about what might happen if you keep drinking.
I know where you're coming from, but I felt like I had it under control that night. I didn't want to be the one who got out of hand, so I made sure my friends were okay too.
It's hard to say when someone is truly in control – anything that involves drinking when you're underage is a concern for me. Let's think about all the potential risks and consequences together.
Yeah, I understand what you're saying. And I do want to make sure my friends are okay too.
How much were you drinking at this party?
To be honest, I don't think it was that much; it was mostly for social gatherings, not something I'd do alone or out of control.
Was it every weekend?
Every other weekend, I guess. But I can see how that might be a concern.
Tommy, I'm really worried about you – is there anything better to do with your time?

Actually, I think I can find more productive ways to spend my time, like focusing on schoolwork and hanging out with other kids who share similar interests. Maybe I've been influenced by the wrong crowd.

You're right; sometimes things seem fun in the moment but aren't good choices later. We talk about making good choices for our lives all the time. Can we work together to come up with a plan that will help you stop drinking?
Yeah, I think that would be a great step forward – maybe being sober and experiencing life more fully.
Okay, let's make a plan to get you in control of your drinking.
That sounds like a good idea.

I want to start by thanking you for being here today and sharing your concerns with me. It sounds like you have a lot on your plate, juggling work, school, and taking care of your two-year-old son. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?

Well, um, I have a two-year-old son, and then I work full time as a server at a restaurant, and then recently, I also started going back to night class, so you know, just the combination of all that, you know. I-I've just been feeling really stressed lately.
I can see why you'd feel overwhelmed. It sounds like you're shouldering a lot of responsibility on your own. Are you a single mom?
Yeah.
So, with three major stressors in your life right now - being a single mom, working full-time, and going back to school - what do you think would be the most helpful for us to focus on today?
